clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Phosphate Binding With Sevelamer in Stage 3 Chronic Kidney Disease
clinical_study.official_title: Does Phosphate Binding With Sevelamer Carbonate Improve Cardiovascular Structure and Function in Patients With Early Chronic Kidney Disease?

lead_sponsor.agency: University Hospital Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

clinical_study.source: University Hospital Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether lowering phosphate in patients with early chronic kidney disease with the phosphate binder sevelamer has beneficial effects on cardiovascular structure and function.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

secondary_outcome.measure: Aortic compliance as measured by cardiac magnetic resonance imaging
Arterial stiffness as measured by pulse wave velocity and pulse wave analysis
Arterial elastance as measured by echocardiography
Left ventricular systolic and diastolic elastance measured by echocardiography
Bone density on dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry scanning

arm_group.description: Treatment group: treatment with 1600mg tablets of sevelamer carbonate three times daily for 36 weeks
Treatment group: treatment with tablets of placebo three times daily for 36 weeks

intervention.description: Treatment group: treatment with 1600mg tablets of sevelamer carbonate three times daily for 36 weeks
Treatment group: treatment with tablets of placebo three times daily for 36 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Chronic kidney disease patients aged 18 to 80 years
- Chronic kidney disease stage 3 (defined as a glomerular filtration rate of 30-60 ml/min/1.73m2)
- Office blood pressure controlled to less than 140/90 mmHg for 12 months before entry into the study
- Total cholesterol less than 5.5 mmol/l
Exclusion Criteria:
- Existing or previous treatment within 1 year with a phosphate binder or vitamin D analogue
- Uncontrolled hyperphosphataemia (serum phosphate >1.8 mmol/l)
- Uncontrolled secondary hyperparathyroidism (PTH >80 pg/ml)
- Diabetes mellitus
- Pregnancy
- Moderate-severe cardiac valvular disease
